column1: Nystagmus is a term to describe fast, uncontrollable movements of the eyes that may be: - Side to side (horizontal nystagmus) - Up and down (vertical nystagmus) - Rotary (rotary or torsional nystagmus) Depending on the cause, these movements may be in both eyes or in just one eye.
The involuntary eye movementseye movements of nystagmus are caused by abnormal function in the areas of the brain that control eye movements.
- Acquired nystagmus develops later in life because of a disease or injury.
NYSTAGMUS THAT IS PRESENT AT BIRTH (infantile nystagmus syndrome, or INS) INS is usually mild.
If the movements are large, sharpness of vision (visual acuity) may be less than 20/20.
Nystagmus may be caused by congenital diseases of the eye.
Phenytoin (Dilantin) - an antiseizure medication, excessive alcohol, or any sedating medicine can impair the labyrinth's function.

Other causes include: - Head injury from motor vehicle accidents - Inner ear disorders such as labyrinthitis or Meniere's disease - Stroke - Thiamine or vitamin B12 deficiency Any disease of the brain (such as multiple sclerosis or brain tumors) can cause nystagmus if the areas controlling eye movements are damaged.
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of nystagmus or think you might have this condition.
Your health care provider will take a careful history and perform a thorough physical examination, focusing on the nervous system and inner ear.
